title: reference request - General treatments of the problem of extending a functor from a small category to its power set to an endofunctor on it?
body: Suppose you analyse a small category $\mathsf{C}$ whose set of objects you again denote by $\mathsf{C}$ . Suppose you have found a natural categorical structure on $2^{\mathsf{C}^{\mathrm{op}}}$ (having much to do with the category $\mathsf{C}$ ). Suppose you have also found a functor $F\colon\mathsf{C}\rightarrow $ $2^{\mathsf{C}^{\mathrm{op}}}$ important to you. Suppose you would like to construct an endofunctor $\overline{F}\colon 2^{\mathsf{C}^{\mathrm{op}}}\rightarrow2^{\mathsf{C}^{\mathrm{op}}}$ naturally 'extending' $F$ , at least in the sense that $\overline{F}(\{O\})=F(O)$ $\quad$ (point.condition) for each object $O$ of $\mathsf{C}$ . Suppose you try this by defining $\overline{F}$ on objects of $2^{\mathsf{C}^{\mathrm{op}}}$ by doing the most obvious: taking the image (in the set-map-sense) under $F$ of any given set of objects of $\mathsf{C}$ . This might or might not work out to give an endofunctor, depending on how the category with set of objects $2^{\mathsf{C}}$ is defined. This is not an 'extension problem' in the most elementary sense of the term, since $\mathsf{C}$ is not a subset of $2^{\mathsf{C}}$ , but a member. Question 0. Are there general treatments of this particular kind of functor extension problem that you would recommend? Question 1. Is there a usual technical term for this extension problem, and is there a, in some precise sense, canonical construction of the endofunctor $\overline{F}$ ? I have seen this process once in the literature, but in a special case, and have forgotten where. Now I need it in my own work, and would like to read general theoretical treatments of it. I am aware of the importance and relevance of embedding a small categories $\textsf{C}$ into its presheaf category $\widehat{\mathsf{C}}$ , which $2^{\mathsf{C}^{\mathrm{op}}}$ is a subcategory of, but could not find a treatment specifically relevant to the extension problem described above. I would like not to explicitly describe my specific problem, not to bias the question and keep in general. Very roughly speaking, the motivation comes from a problem in algebraic geometry, with $\mathsf{C}$ corresponding to some sort of variety equipped with a notion of morphisms between its points, the points of $\mathsf{C}$ parametrize a notion $S$ of `set of equations' each of whose possible solutions is again a point of $\mathsf{C}$ , $F$ describes the correspondence ( $\mathsf{C}\ni O \mapsto F(O) = $ set of all solutions to the set of equations $S(O)$ $\in$ $2^{\mathsf{C}}$ ) The goal is to extend $F$ to an endofunctor of the kind described above which formalizes the correspondence ( $2^{\mathsf{C}}\ni \mathbb{O} \mapsto \overline{F}(\mathbb{O}) = $ set of all solutions to the set of equations $\bigcup_{O\in\mathbb{O}}S(O)$ $\in$ $2^{\mathsf{C}}$ ) Moreover, I know at least one $O\in\mathsf{C}$ with $F(O)=\emptyset$ . Therefore,another necessary condition on the endofunctor $\overline{F}$ is $\overline{F}(\mathsf{C})=\emptyset$ . reference-request ct.category-theory mathematical-writing Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 15, 2020 at 7:27 Community Bot 1 2 2 silver badges 3 3 bronze badges asked May 12, 2017 at 15:22 Peter Heinig 6,151 1 1 gold badge 30 30 silver badges 50 50 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 2 $\begingroup$ If you don't forget that $\sf C$ is a category you can endow $2^{\sf C}$ with a category structure in a pretty much standard way: it is the category of functors ${\sf C}\to 2$ and natural transformations. It's up to you now to say whether $2=\{0,1\}$ or $2=\{0\le 1\}$, but in both cases it is a category ($\sf C\times C$ in the first case, and something a little bit more complicated in the other case. $\endgroup$ fosco –  fosco 2017-05-12 16:17:51 +00:00 Commented May 12, 2017 at 16:17 1 $\begingroup$ I'll just throw an irresponsible answer, ok? If you can find a functor $y\colon {\sf C}\to 2^{\sf C}$ out of the Yoneda embedding (let's say for example that you send $c\in\sf C$ to the composition ${\sf C} \overset{y}\to [{\sf C}^\text{op}, {\bf Sets}] \overset{[{\sf C}^\text{op},empty?]}\to [{\sf C}^\text{op},2]$, where $empty?\colon {\bf Set}\to 2$ does the obvious thing) then you can perform a Kan extension. Nontriviality of this extension is far from being granted, of course. :-) $\endgroup$ fosco –  fosco 2017-05-12 17:17:35 +00:00 Commented May 12, 2017 at 17:17 1 $\begingroup$ @FoscoLoregian, when $2=\{0,1\}$, isn't it the case that the category $2^\mathsf{C}$ is the powerset of connected components of $\mathsf{C}$, not $\mathsf{C}\times\mathsf{C}$? $\endgroup$ Kaya Arro –  Kaya Arro 2017-05-14 16:53:33 +00:00 Commented May 14, 2017 at 16:53 $\begingroup$ Sure, you're right.
